page.title: 06CHURCHES
page.content: {ST GERMAIN CHURCH AT WINESTEAD} Under the Benefice of the Rector of Patrington it is situated in a field surrounded by farmland and trees. The Church, having only 25 pews, has been in use since 1242. It contains three stained glass windows and 18th century Hildyard memorials, one of which being an altar tomb. The Chancel contains a large stone having brass effigies of a knight and lady with smaller brasses at their feet representing their family; seven sons and six daughters and is reputed to be a memorail of Sir Robert Hildyard of Winestead KNT, commonly called "Robin of Riddesdale" during the War of the Roses. The lighting in the main body of the Church is by candles in a hanging brass chandelier, with electric lights to the choir stalls. The pipe organ is free standing.
